tit.e: Kotaiyoriai (alternate yoriai, a family status of samurai warriors in the Edo Period)
tit.cmt: took out description as it is written in further detail directly below

sen.j: 交代寄合（こうたいよりあい）は、江戸幕府における旗本の家格の一つ。
sen.e: Kotaiyoriai (交代寄合) is a family status of hatamoto (a direct retainer of a shogun) in Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
Kotaiyoriai (交代寄合） is one instance of having hatamoto (a direct retainter of a shogun) family status within the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
Kotaiyoriai (交代寄合） is one instance of having hatamoto (a direct retainer of a shogun) family status within the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 広義の旗本寄合席に含まれる。
sen.e: It is one of Hatamoto Yoriaiseki (a family rank of high-ranking hatamoto, direct vassal of a shogun) in the broad sense.
In a broad sense, the status was the same as a high-ranking retainer (hatamoto yoriaiseki) that also meant being a direct vassal of the shogun.
sen.cmt: changed sentence order; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: In a broad sense, the status was the same as a high-ranking retainer (hatamoto yoriaiseki) that also meant being a direct vassal of the shogun.

sen.j: 江戸定府の旗本寄合席に対して参勤交代を行う寄合の意。
sen.e: It means Yoriai (a meeting) to make the top decision about Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo Period were required to spend every year in residence in Edo), while Hatamoto Yoriaiseki is a resident retainer in continuous presence in Edo bakufu.
sen.cmt: 江戸定府→定訳不明：continuous presence in Edo bakufuとしました。
sen.e: Unlike Hatamoto Yoriaiseki who had continuous residence in Edo, Kotaiyoriai participated in a system called "Sankinkotai" which obligated feudal lords to reside in Edo every other year to show their loyalty to the shogunate.
sen.cmt: Why was "席" added on this version when it is written only as "旗本寄合" in the wikipedia article? <http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/交代寄合>
sen.e: Unlike Hatamoto Yoriaiseki who had continuous residence in Edo, Kotaiyoriai participated in a system called Sankinkotai which obligated feudal lords to reside in Edo every other year to show their loyalty to the shogunate.

sen.j: 交代寄合の用語は1703年（元禄16年）刊行の武鑑が初出。
sen.e: The term Kotaiyoriai appeared in "Bukan" (a book of heraldry) published in 1703 for the first time.
The term Kotaiyoriai appeared in "Bukan" (a book of heraldry), published for the first time in 1703.
sen.cmt: changed sentence structure to read more smoothly
sen.e: The term Kotaiyoriai appeared in Bukan (a book of heraldry), published for the first time in 1703.

sen.j: 20家が表向御礼衆と呼ばれるようになるのは元文期（1736-1740）頃という。
sen.e: It is said that twenty families had come to be called Omotemuki onreishu (twenty families with a special high rank among Kotaiyoriai members) in the period between 1736 and 1740.
sen.cmt: 表向御礼衆→定訳不明：Omotemuki onreishu (twenty families with a special high rank among Kotaiyoriai members)としました。
sen.e: It is reported that among Kotaiyoriai members, twenty families were given a special high rank called "Omotemuki onreishi" between 1736 and 1740.
It is reported that among Kotaiyoriai members, twenty families were given a special high rank called Omotemuki onreishu between 1736 and 1740.

sen.j: 禄高が1万石以下でありながら“大身旗本”として大名と同様に参勤交代することを許されていた。
sen.e: Although their stipend is less than ten thousands Koku crop yields, there were treated as "taishin hatamoto" (hatamoto with a high rank and high yields), and they were permitted to practice Sankinkotai like daimyo (feudal lord).
sen.cmt: 大身旗本→定訳不明：taishin hatamoto" (hatamoto with a high rank and high yields)としました。
sen.e: Although the stipend for a Kotaiyoriai was less than ten thousand koku (crop yields), they were treated as "taishin hatamoto" (hatamoto with high rank and high yields) and permitted to practice Sankinkotai like daimyo feudal lords.

Although the stipend for a Kotaiyoriai was less than ten thousand koku (crop yields), they were treated as "taishin hatamoto" (hatamoto with high rank and high yields) and permitted to practice Sankinkotai like daimyo feudal lords.

sen.j: 旗本寄合が若年寄支配であるのに対し、旗本交代寄合は老中支配となる。
sen.e: While, Hatamotoyoriai (a hatamoto meeting) was dominated by those in wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu), Hatamoto Kotaiyoriai was lead by roju (members of shoguns council of elders).
sen.cmt: 老中→定訳不明：roju (members of shoguns council of elders)としました。
sen.e: While Hatamotoyoriai (hatamoto meetings) were dominated by wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu), Kotaiyoriai meetings were lead by the Roju (members of the Shogun's council of elders).
While Hatamotoyoriai (hatamoto meetings) were dominated by wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu), Kotaiyoriai meetings were lead by the Roju (members of the Shogun's council of elders).

sen.j: また、伺候席が帝鑑間詰であっても役職に就くことはなかった。
sen.e: Even though their shikoseki (anteroom seats of feudal lords and direct retainer of the shogun at the Edo-jo Castle) were for those called Teikan no ma Zume (warriors who are were supposed to wait in Teikan-no-ma, a waiting room with the painting of famous Chinese emperors, before meeting Shogun in Hakusho-in meeting room), they held no post in the government (bakufu).
sen.cmt: 帝鑑間詰→定訳不明：Teikan no ma Zume (warriors who are were supposed to wait in Teikan-no-ma, a waiting room with the painting of famous Chinese emperors, before meeting the shogun in Hakusho-in meeting room)としました。
sen.e: Even though Kotaiyoriai used the same anteroom seats (shikoseki) in Edo Castle as feudal lords and direct retainers of the Shogun, they held no official position in the government.
sen.cmt: Eliminated "Teikan-no-ma" details here since they are written again below;
sen.e: Even though Kotaiyoriai used the same anteroom seats (shikoseki) in Edo-jo Castle as feudal lords and direct retainers of the Shogun, they held no official position in the government.

sen.j: 寄合御役金は100石に付き金2両の割合で8月と2月の分納であった。
sen.e: 寄合御役金Yoriai oyakukin (monthly salary) was paid in a lump sum twice a year, in August and February, with the proportion of 2 両ryo (unit of gold currency) on each 100 Koku stipend crop yield.
All retainers were paid a yoriai oyakukin (stipend) in lump sum twice a year in February and August at a proportion of two units of ryo (unit of gold currency) for each 100 koku (crop yield).
sen.cmt: took out kanji; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: All retainers were paid a yoriai oyakukin (stipend) in lump sum twice a year in February and August at a proportion of two units of ryo (unit of gold currency) for each 100 koku (crop yield).

sen.j: 特別の由緒がある地方の豪族や大名家の分家、改易された大名家の名跡を継ぐもの等が列せられた。
sen.e: It was composed of those who were from a local ruling family with a long and distinguished history and a branch of daimyo (feudal lord) families, and the successors to Myoseki (name of family) to a daimyo family which underwent the change of rank, among others.
sen.cmt: 豪族→local ruling family [英辞郎on the WEB] 改易→change of rank [Webster's Online Dictionary]
sen.e: Kotaiyoriai members were composed of local ruling families with a long and distinguished history, branch families of daimyo feudal lords, successors to a daimyo family name thus undergoing a change in rank, etc..
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more smoothly; among others→etc;
sen.e: Kotaiyoriai members were composed of local ruling families with a long and distinguished history, branch families of daimyo feudal lords, successors to a daimyo family name thus undergoing a change in rank, etc.

sen.j: 伺候席は、“帝鑑間”または“柳間”とされ大名と同等の待遇を受けた。
sen.e: For their shikoseki (anteroom seats) before meeting Shogun, "Teikan no ma" (a waiting room with the paintings of famous Chinese emperors in the Edo-jo Castle) or "Yanagi no ma" (a waiting room with the painting of willows for middle-rank warriors in the Edo-jo Castle) were designated and they enjoyed the same treatment as daimyo.
sen.cmt: 帝鑑間→定訳不明："Teikan no ma" (a waiting room with the paintings of famous Chinese emperors in the Edo-jo Castle) 柳間→定訳不明："Yanagi no ma" (a waiting room with the painting of willows for middle-rank warriors in the Edo-jo Castle)としました。
sen.e: Before meeting the shogun in Edo Castle, Kotaiyoriai enjoyed the same treatment as daimyo feudal lords and were designated shikoseki (anteroom seats) in a room called "Teikan no ma" with paintings of famous Chinese emperors, or in a room meant for middle-rank warriors with paintings of willows called "Yanagi no ma,"

sen.j: 官位については、一部の例外を除いて通常の旗本と同様に役職就任時以外の任官はなかった。
sen.e: The same as hatamoto, they were not given an official rank, unless they were appointed to a certain official position, except for several cases.
Aside from a few cases, Kotaiyoriai did not have an official rank unless they were appointed one, the same as any other hatamoto retainer.
sen.cmt: several→a few; changed structure to read more natural
sen.e: Aside from a few cases, Kotaiyoriai did not have an official rank unless they were appointed one, the same as any other hatamoto retainer.
